pullrequest.title: Issue #73: Optitrack marker arithmetic based on monitor axes

content.raw: What if the diagonal elements of `G` are all `-1` (negative identity matrix)? Should you take the absolute value of the numbers inside the square root?
content.html: What if the diagonal elements of G are all -1 (negative identity matrix)? Should you take the absolute value of the numbers inside the square root?

pullrequest.title: Issue #73: Optitrack marker arithmetic based on monitor axes

content.raw: indeed. I should implement a [more stable numerical method](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rotation_matrix#Quaternion) for the case where the trace is >=-1 or `qw` is 0
content.html: indeed. I should implement a more stable numerical method for the case where the trace is >=-1 or qw is 0

pullrequest.title: Issue #73: Optitrack marker arithmetic based on monitor axes

content.raw: I think for now I will leave it and add a warning for the invalid case, but come back to this when there's a more robust, tested method in Gazebo math (or ign-math?).
content.html: I think for now I will leave it and add a warning for the invalid case, but come back to this when there's a more robust, tested method in Gazebo math (or ign-math?).

content.raw: would [std::sort](http://www.cplusplus.com/reference/algorithm/sort/) be useful here?

pullrequest.title: Issue #73: Optitrack marker arithmetic based on monitor axes

content.raw: it would probably mean calling sort on a `std::vector<std::pair<double, int>>` to sort by length and also preserve which index corresponds to which length. This kind of manipulation is still a lot nicer in Python than it is in C++...
content.html: it would probably mean calling sort on a std::vector<std::pair<double, int>> to sort by length and also preserve which index corresponds to which length. This kind of manipulation is still a lot nicer in Python than it is in C++...

pullrequest.title: Issue #73: Optitrack marker arithmetic based on monitor axes

content.raw: oh, I was just thinking to sort the `points` vector, but I guess you do need the index as well...
content.html: oh, I was just thinking to sort the points vector, but I guess you do need the index as well...

pullrequest.title: Issue #73: Optitrack marker arithmetic based on monitor axes

content.raw:
I think we got the orientation issue resolved finally (head tracking motion is not dictated by the orientation of the glasses after this PR).

As Carlos mentioned, there is still a slight skew in axis due to offset treatment, but I think this PR is a good upgrade from status-quo and like to get this incremental improvement out with next release by Friday.
content.html:
I think we got the orientation issue resolved finally (head tracking motion is not dictated by the orientation of the glasses after this PR).

As Carlos mentioned, there is still a slight skew in axis due to offset treatment, but I think this PR is a good upgrade from status-quo and like to get this incremental improvement out with next release by Friday.

content.raw: Why are we using a `unique_lock` with `std::try_to_lock` here? If we want to use this type of lock we should verify that we have acquired the mutex with `monitorLock.owns_lock()`.
content.html: Why are we using a unique_lock with std::try_to_lock here? If we want to use this type of lock we should verify that we have acquired the mutex with monitorLock.owns_lock().

pullrequest.title: Issue #73: Optitrack marker arithmetic based on monitor axes

content.raw: Now, we're using `this->optitrackMonitorMutex` instead of `this->viewpointRotationMutex`. Just checking, is this on purpose?
content.html: Now, we're using this->optitrackMonitorMutex instead of this->viewpointRotationMutex. Just checking, is this on purpose?

pullrequest.title: Issue #73: Optitrack marker arithmetic based on monitor axes

content.raw:
It's really two cases... `viewpointRotationMutex` is accessed in `OnToggleViewpointRotations`, while `optitrackMonitorMutex` is for the monitor pose

I think this is a good time for our friend `std::atomic<bool>`
content.html:
It's really two cases... viewpointRotationMutex is accessed in OnToggleViewpointRotations, while optitrackMonitorMutex is for the monitor pose

I think this is a good time for our friend std::atomic<bool>

pullrequest.title: Issue #73: Optitrack marker arithmetic based on monitor axes

content.raw:
I've been testing the pull request and found the following issues:

* The camera view moves if you move the OptiTrack camera in play mo-cap mode. If you pause mo-cap, move OptiTrack, and then unpause mo-cap, it looks OK. We agreed to fix this issue in the future as it doesn't seem a situation that teams will do.
* Camera view changes if you toggle the `Enable viewpoint rotations` button without pause mo-cap. Fixed by @hsu.
* There's still a small vibration in the viewpoint. We have concludes that this is caused by camera calibration due to lightining conditions during testing.

Other than that, it looks good to me. Good job!
content.html:
I've been testing the pull request and found the following issues:

  • The camera view moves if you move the OptiTrack camera in play mo-cap mode. If you pause mo-cap, move OptiTrack, and then unpause mo-cap, it looks OK. We agreed to fix this issue in the future as it doesn't seem a situation that teams will do.
  • Camera view changes if you toggle the Enable viewpoint rotations button without pause mo-cap. Fixed by @hsu.
  • There's still a small vibration in the viewpoint. We have concludes that this is caused by camera calibration due to lightining conditions during testing.

Other than that, it looks good to me. Good job!

pullrequest.title: Issue #73: Optitrack marker arithmetic based on monitor axes

content.raw:
Two notes:

* As @caguero noted, there's still some noticeable vibration.  @hsu and @jacquelinekay said that they'll re-enable the filter on the OptiTrack pose data, in a separate PR.
* The arm pose is not invariant to camera pose, in that if you move the camera during a run, the arm won't do the right thing.  But, importantly, you can always get back to a working state by pausing and resetting the scene, no matter where the camera is (as long as all the markers are in view, of course).
content.html:
Two notes:

  • As @caguero noted, there's still some noticeable vibration. @hsu and @jacquelinekay said that they'll re-enable the filter on the OptiTrack pose data, in a separate PR.
  • The arm pose is not invariant to camera pose, in that if you move the camera during a run, the arm won't do the right thing. But, importantly, you can always get back to a working state by pausing and resetting the scene, no matter where the camera is (as long as all the markers are in view, of course).
